awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Marine Conservation, Demography, and Family Planning
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). 

Some efforts to manage natural resources have relied on family planning initiatives designed to address broader demographic concerns about population rise. This doctoral dissertation project examines how an understanding of overpopulation connects to efforts to slow fertility rates in vulnerable ecosystems, and what relationship the resulting family planning initiatives have with reproductive behavior. This research project asks how environmental scientists and organizations understand and communicate the relationship between reproduction and conservation. In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student in anthropology in the methods of empirical, findings will be disseminated to stakeholder organizations that shape the design and implementation of conservation programs. This project also broadens the participation of groups underrepresented in science.

This doctoral dissertation research project explores the relationship between family planning and environmental conservation policies aimed at addressing population concerns. Through an ethnographic study of demographers, marine scientists, family planning practitioners, and women participating in family planning, the project examines the processes underlying the production of population data, and the relationship these dynamics have to women’s own experiences and understandings of reproductive freedom. Ultimately, this study contributes to new understandings of the ways in which demography and reproductive policy shape women’s reproductive lives. The methods include participant observation, semi-structured interviews and life history interviews with demographic scientists, community-based family planning practitioners, and women of reproductive age, as well as archival data analysis and supply chain mapping. The project contributes to a growing scholarship on the environmental dimensions of reproduction, and advances scholarship in political ecology and science studies more broadly.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This award was originally intended to fund doctoral dissertation research on family planning and marine conservation in coastal Madagascar. The project was based on three years of Masters-level and preliminary doctoral research in the island’s northwest mangrove communities. However, shortly after the funding of this project, the Covid-19 pandemic halted all international research projects. The Malagasy state restricted access to Madagascar, impeding international travel for research. As a result, the co-PI (M.L.) was unable to access her field site. The project’s intended location was in a rural, forest-dependent community, where residents have limited phone and internet access. These conditions made it nearly impossible to conduct research interviews remotely.

In the face of these serious obstacles to this research project, the co-PI made the difficult decision to shift her project field site to an accessible location within the United States. The project remained focused on the social dimensions of reproductive medicine. However, rather than family planning, the project would now center the practices and experiences of infertility within the U.S.

After spending considerable time sourcing field sites, establishing research relationships, obtaining new IRB approval, and completing HIPPA training, fieldwork began at the outset of 2022. The project would now take place in three in vitro fertilization (IVF) clinics in the northeast United States. The exact names and locations of these clinics remain anonymous to protect the privacy of research participants. While set in a different location and among new actors, the project’s methods remained fundamentally unchanged. The co-PI conducted daily participant observation in a variety of clinical settings, interacting with physicians, nurses, embryologists, and IVF patients. She observed and learned the processes of IVF care, including patient consultations, exams, and procedures. She also spent considerable time alongside clinic embryologists to learn the practices of embryo culture.

The project’s questions were heavily influenced by the June 2022 Supreme Court decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization, as practitioners and patients in the sphere of IVF adapted to a new political and juridical landscape. As gestating and IVF embryos became the focus of much national attention, I examined how IVF’s varied stakeholders conceptualized the embryos they facilitated, cultured, and handled (in the case of IVF professionals) or intended to parent (in the case of IVF patients). Alongside 15 months of participant observation, I also conducted 30 conversational interviews with clinicians, embryologists, and patients. Data revealed that embryos take on a variety of meanings in the context of IVF, and that these meanings often co-occur. Moreover, owing to their interactions with patients, clinicians play a large role in fostering patients’ (and thus, the public’s) understandings of embryos. Clinicians’ use of language, and understandings of embryos, become politicized when they and their patients take those understandings outside clinic walls.

In Fall 2023, findings were published in the medical anthropology website Somatosphere. This article allowed participants to learn about and engage in the project’s initial conclusions. Following the completion of fieldwork in spring 2024, project findings were presented to clinicians at participating IVF clinics. Over two clinical presentations, participants discussed project findings and the implications for their own practices. Results were presented to academic audiences in conferences including the Association of American Anthropologists annual meeting, and the Society for the Social Studies of Science annual meeting. I also wrote up the project’s findings in a book-length dissertation, which I successfully defended in May 2024. In 2025, results will be further discussed in forthcoming articles in Medical Anthropology Quarterly and Fertility and Sterility, two journals with diverse audiences. Supplementary articles are planned for journals in anthropology and bioethics, culminating in the publication of this project in book form.

 

 


Last Modified: 01/17/2025
Modified by: Manon Lefevre
